children.text: Docker Environment — Docker compose setup to bring up local environment and services
Pull and pin the WordPress PHP-FPM image (use exact tag)
Configure environment variables and DB connection for container
Mount plugin source into container for development
Add PHP-FPM `www.conf` and php.ini overrides for dev
Add container healthcheck and CI integration tests
Document WP-CLI helper commands and test entrypoints
Map DB volume to host path for backups (e.g., `docker/mysql_data`) — recommended for easy host-level backups and inspection
Add DB seeding for tests (e.g., `tests/db-seed.php`) to enable repeatable test setups
Configure MySQL environment variables and credentials for compose
Add DB healthcheck and readiness probe for compose
Secure collection: document backup/restore steps and credentials handling
Let's Encrypt automation: use Certbot/lego/nginx-proxy-companion or consider Caddy for automatic issuance and renewal
Auto-renewal handling: mount certificates to a volume and add a post-renewal reload hook to reload Nginx
HTTP→HTTPS redirect: expose port 80 only for redirects and ACME challenges; force HTTPS for site traffic
Strong TLS policy: enable TLS 1.2+ and TLS 1.3, set explicit cipher suites, and disable weak ciphers and legacy protocols
HSTS header: configure `Strict-Transport-Security` with an appropriate `max-age` and document preload considerations
OCSP stapling and TLS session caching: enable for improved performance and certificate validation
Container healthcheck & logging: add a simple health endpoint and stream access/error logs to stdout/stderr
Volume & secret management: document where certs/keys live and how secrets are injected (avoid baking keys into images)
Graceful reloads and scaling: ensure zero-downtime reload strategy when certs or config change (signal handling, rolling reloads)
Optional extras: mutual TLS (client certs), rate-limiting, security headers (CSP, X-Frame-Options), and IPv6 support
Add a Redis service to `docker/docker-compose.yml` and expose it to the PHP and WordPress containers
Install and enable the PHP `redis` extension in the PHP-FPM image (document Dockerfile/build steps)
Add a WordPress `object-cache.php` drop-in (or enable the Redis Object Cache plugin) and document configuration (host, port, and env vars)
Add a Redis healthcheck and optional volume for persistence in development
Document example `docker-compose.override.yml` and environment variable examples for local development
REQUIRED - DB connectivity: set `PMA_HOST=db` so phpMyAdmin connects to the MySQL service
REQUIRED - Credentials: use the MySQL env vars (e.g., `MYSQL_ROOT_PASSWORD`, `MYSQL_USER`, `MYSQL_PASSWORD`, `MYSQL_DATABASE`) for authentication
REQUIRED - Network: attach phpMyAdmin to the same Docker network as the MySQL service
REQUIRED - Port mapping: expose phpMyAdmin on host `8080:80` for local access
GOOD - Blowfish secret: set `PMA_BLOWFISH_SECRET` for cookie encryption
GOOD - Localhost binding: bind host port to `127.0.0.1:8080` when running locally to limit external access
GOOD - Healthcheck: add a simple HTTP healthcheck for container reliability
GOOD - depends_on: add a `depends_on` for MySQL readiness (or a wait-for script) to ensure startup order
GOOD - Override file: keep phpMyAdmin service config in `docker-compose.override.yml` for dev-only settings
GOOD - Documentation: add usage notes (URL, default credentials, env var references) to docs/
NOT REQUIRED - Persistence: phpMyAdmin is stateless; no persistent volume required for typical dev use
NOT REQUIRED - Reverse proxy: unnecessary for simple localhost development
NOT REQUIRED - TLS/Traefik labels: skip for local dev; use in production only
NOT REQUIRED - Alternative notes: mention alternatives (Adminer, remote DB tools) under this topic for reference
Custom healthcheck scripts for all services
Docker Compose v3.8+ with environment variable substitution
Volume mounts for plugin development directory
Automated database seeding with sample data
Folder Structure — create folder structure and repository layout
Framework: WORDPRESS PLUGIN STRUCTURE (with Tailwind + Vite)
Make plugin standalone, production ready; can be installed in any website and works instantly without modifying or re-editing code
Plugin should be ready to upload in CodeCanyon or any third‑party seller
Use standard code that aligns with WordPress core and industry best practices (security, standards)
Do cleanup step-by-step during work, then run a final release polish pass at the end
Code should be ready to integrate with any cache plugin
Git Repository — initialize Git repository and basic branches
Create develop branch for active development
Create feature/* branches for new features
Create hotfix/* branches for critical fixes
Create release/* branches for version releases
Branch protection rules (no direct push to main)
Composer Configuration — composer.json and related setup
Scripts with test, lint, analyze commands
Environment Variables — .env for dev, WP Options fallback
WordPress Options API fallback for all settings
Security note: 'Never store API keys in .env on production'
WordPress Path/URL Functions — canonical helpers for URLs and paths
Database Table Prefix — configurable DB prefix and migration notes
Standalone & Privacy Guarantees — standalone mode, data handling, privacy
Zero external HTTP requests during normal operation
No Google Fonts or any web font service
No Font Awesome or external icon libraries
No Google Analytics, Mixpanel, Segment, etc.
No external image URLs (reject on submission)
No external JS libraries loaded via CDN
No phone-home behavior of any kind
All assets bundled and loaded locally
No built-in analytics/tracking (handled by Site Kit / separate plugin)
No external API calls except user-clicked affiliate links
CAPTCHA disabled by default (optional, no external service code)
README prominently states '100% Standalone - No External Dependencies'
README lists all bundled vs. excluded dependencies
Code Quality Tools — PHPCS, PHPUnit, linters and config
Lint-staged configuration for staged files only
Pre-commit: Run PHPCS on PHP files
Pre-commit: Run PHPStan on PHP files
Pre-commit: Run Psalm on PHP files
Pre-commit: Run ESLint on JS/TS files
Pre-commit: Run Prettier on JS/TS files
Pre-commit: Run Stylelint on CSS files
Pre-commit: Check for `strict_types=1` in all PHP files
Pre-commit: Check for merge conflict markers
Commit-msg hook: Validate conventional commits format
README Documentation — installation, local setup, and developer notes
Show in menu: true with custom icon
Custom capabilities: edit, read, delete, edit_others, publish, read_private
Supports: title, editor, thumbnail, excerpt, author, revisions
Custom REST fields for meta data
Meta box callback: custom hierarchical UI
Term meta: hide from menu flag
Meta box callback: custom tag UI with autocomplete
Meta box: custom UI for ribbon selection
Ribbon meta: ribbon position (top-left, top-right, bottom-left, bottom-right)
Ribbon meta: ribbon style (badge, corner, banner, diagonal)
Ribbon meta: icon (SVG or Heroicon name)
Full PHPDoc block on every class
Full PHPDoc block on every method
Full PHPDoc block on every function
Return type declarations for all methods
Tabbed interface: General, Pricing, Links, Features, Media, Advanced
Meta box field dependency logic (show/hide based on other fields)
This plugin does not include built-in analytics or tracking functionality.
Actions (Edit, Quick Edit, Trash, View, Duplicate)
Sort by price (low to high, high to low)
Update price (bulk, with percentage or fixed increase/decrease)
Widget: Quick Links (Add Product, View Submissions, Settings)
Form: Product Info, Pricing, Media, Contact
Allowed file types: JPEG, PNG, WebP, GIF (configurable)
Blocked file types: PHP, JS, EXE, BAT, SH, etc.
Magic bytes validation (verify actual file type)
Total upload size limit per submission
Store uploads in secure directory (non-public or .htaccess protected)
Generate unique filenames to prevent overwrite
Reject SVG uploads (XSS risk) unless explicitly allowed with sanitization
Reject polyglot files (multiple valid file types)
Check for hidden PHP code in images
Verify GD or Imagick can process the image
Reject data URIs pointing to external sources
Upload error handling with user-friendly messages
Rate limit file uploads per IP
Type casting for expected data types
Never use variables directly in SQL queries
Late escaping (escape at output, not input)
Validate data types (string, int, bool, array)
Nonce in URL query strings (when needed)
Map capabilities to roles (Administrator, Editor, Author, Contributor)
Allow role customization via plugin settings
Check capabilities in REST API endpoints
Check capabilities before meta box display
Never use variables in table/column names (use whitelisting)
Limit submission form to 3 per hour per IP
Limit submission form to 10 per day per user
Limit AJAX requests to 60 per minute per IP
Limit API requests to 100 per hour per key
Store rate limit data in transients
Whitelist trusted IPs from rate limiting
Different limits for authenticated vs anonymous users
Rate limit statistics in admin dashboard
Time-based CAPTCHA (min time to fill form)
CAPTCHA only after X failed attempts
No external CAPTCHA service code bundled
Log security violations (failed nonce, capability, etc.)
Store logs in custom database table
Log rotation (delete logs older than 90 days)
Log filtering by type, date, user, IP
Never log sensitive data (passwords, payment info)
Detect repeated submissions (same IP, same data)
Check for spam keywords in content
Check for excessive links in content
Integration with Akismet (optional, external service disclaimer)
Theme: custom color palette (primary, secondary, accent, neutral, success, warning, error)
Theme: custom breakpoints (sm, md, lg, xl, 2xl)
Content paths: all PHP, JS, TS files
Safelist: dynamic classes for colors, sizes
Vite: Source maps in dev, not in prod
Vite: Dev server with HMR (Hot Module Replacement)
Vite: Dev server proxy for WordPress (if needed)
NPM scripts: `npm run dev`, `npm run build`, `npm run preview`
Ensure all compiled CSS/JS bundled in `dist/`
No external CDN links in enqueued assets
System font stack: `system-ui, -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, 'Helvetica Neue', Arial, sans-serif`
Monospace stack: `ui-monospace, SFMono-Regular, 'SF Mono', Menlo, Consolas, 'Liberation Mono', monospace`
No Google Fonts or any external web font service
No web font CDNs (Google Fonts, Adobe Fonts, etc.)
Typography settings: font size, line height, letter spacing
Typography settings: link style (color, underline, hover)
Use bundled local SVG icons only
No Font Awesome or external icon libraries
No icon CDNs (Font Awesome CDN, etc.)
Icon size prop (sm, md, lg, xl)
Custom icon support (upload SVG to library)
All images stored locally (WordPress media library)
Reject external image URLs in product card
Reject external image URLs in admin meta box
Reject external image URLs in submission form
Validate image URLs on save (check domain)
Use WordPress image sizes (thumbnail, medium, large, full)
Image alt text (required, fallback to product title)
Image zoom on hover or click
Video support (local upload or embed code, no YouTube API)
Image security: serve with proper headers
No external JS libraries from CDNs
No dynamic imports from external URLs
Script versioning (plugin version or file hash)
Conditional script loading (only on pages that need it)
Defer or async attributes where appropriate
Security: escape all PHP-to-JS data with `wp_json_encode()`
Security: nonce in JS global object
Security: REST API URL in JS global object
Performance: tree shaking to remove unused code
No jQuery dependency (use vanilla JS or React)
Custom CSS in separate file (loaded after Tailwind)
Style versioning (plugin version or file hash)
Inline critical CSS for above-the-fold content
CSS grid and flexbox for layouts
Dark mode support (class-based, toggle in settings)
Grid gap: xs, sm, md, lg, xl (configurable)
Filter by category (dropdown or checkbox list)
Filter by tag (dropdown or checkbox list)
Filter by ribbon (dropdown or checkbox list)
Filter by brand (dropdown or checkbox list, searchable)
Filter by price range (slider or min/max inputs)
Filter by stock status (In Stock, Out of Stock)
Sort by price: low to high
Sort by price: high to low
Sort by rating: high to low
URL parameter sync (filters and sort in query string)
Filter result count ('Showing X of Y products')
URL parameter sync (page in query string)
Scroll to top on page change (optional)
Load more button option (alternative to pagination)
Search filters (combine with category, price, etc.)
URL parameter sync (search query in URL)
Prevent body scroll when modal open
Modal animation (fade in, slide up, zoom)
Modal sizes (sm, md, lg, xl, full)
Empty state: no results for search
No any type (use unknown or specific type)
Use React.FC or function component with explicit return type
React Hooks: useState, useEffect, useContext, useReducer
React Context for global state (filters, settings)
ESLint: Template literals over string concatenation
Prettier: JSX brackets on same line (false)
Attribute: exclude (product IDs to exclude, comma-separated)
Attribute: on_sale (true/false, show only on sale)
Attribute: in_stock (true/false, show only in stock)
Attribute: limit (number of products to show, default 12)
Attribute: orderby (featured, date, title, price, rating, random)
Attribute: filter (true/false, show filter bar, default false)
Attribute: search (true/false, show search bar, default false)
Attribute: sort (true/false, show sort dropdown, default false)
Shortcode builder in admin (GUI for generating shortcodes)
AJAX handler: return product HTML or data
Query only needed fields (no unnecessary meta queries)
Use meta_query for meta field filters
Use update_post_meta_cache=>false if meta not needed
Use update_post_term_cache=>false if terms not needed
Use object caching (Redis, Memcached if available)
Set transient expiration (1 hour for dynamic data)
Database indexes on meta_key, meta_value if queried often
Avoid slow queries (nested meta queries, complex tax queries)
Use direct SQL for complex queries (with $wpdb->prepare)
Monitor slow queries (Query Monitor plugin in dev)
Query result pagination (don't load all results)
Cache random results per user session (avoid recalculation)
Exclude recently shown products (for returning visitors)
Random rotation (show different products on refresh)
Performance: limit random query to small subset first, then randomize
Get affiliate link from product meta
Add UTM parameters to link (from settings)
Open in new tab/window (via JS, not redirect)
Interstitial page (optional, 'You are leaving our site')
Security: validate redirect URL (no open redirects)
Security: rate limit redirects per IP
Admin: test affiliate link (check if live)
Admin: broken link checker (scan all links)
Admin: link expiration dates (warn before expiration)
Admin: link rotation (A/B test different links)
Admin: link shortening (built-in, no external service)
Admin: link preview (show destination before redirect)
Admin: link notes (internal notes for each link)
Link import (CSV with product ID + link)
Link validation on save (check URL format)
Link attribution (via UTM parameters; recommend external analytics for attribution)
Link audit log (who changed what, when)
Tabbed interface: General, Styling, Advanced, Import/Export, Help
Settings API: WordPress Settings API + REST API
Save settings via AJAX (no page reload)
Settings documentation (help text for each setting)
Pagination type (numbered, prev/next, load more, infinite scroll)
Show pagination info ("Showing X of Y")
Scroll to top on page change
Enable single product page (or redirect to affiliate link)
Share networks (Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, Pinterest, Email)
Max submissions per user per day
Allowed file types (JPEG, PNG, WebP, GIF)
Dark mode auto (based on system preference)
Link style (underline, no underline, hover underline)
Card border style (solid, dashed, dotted, none)
Card shadow (none, sm, md, lg, xl, 2xl)
Card hover effect (lift, shadow, border, none)
Button text (custom default text, e.g., "View Deal")
Button icon type (arrow, external link, etc.)
Stock badge color (in stock, out of stock)
Image hover effect (zoom, fade, slide, none)
Responsive breakpoints (sm, md, lg, xl, custom)
Animation easing (ease, linear, ease-in, ease-out, ease-in-out)
CSS priority (load order: plugin CSS → custom CSS)
Rate limit: submissions per hour per IP
Rate limit: submissions per day per user
Rate limit: AJAX requests per minute
Lazy load threshold (px before entering viewport)
Import validation (dry run before actual import)
Debug log level (error, warning, info, debug)
REST API authentication (WordPress auth, API key, both)
Custom hook documentation (link to developer docs)
Export excludes: API keys, sensitive data
Import preview (show what will be imported)
Export filtered products (based on current filters)
CSV column mapping tool (map CSV columns to product fields)
Import mode (create new, update existing, both)
Match existing by (ID, slug, SKU, title)
Dry run option (preview import without actually importing)
Import validation (check data types, required fields)
Quick start guide (steps to add first product)
Bug report form (link to GitHub issues)
Check for updates tool (disabled if update checker removed)
Plugin reset tool (reset all settings, with confirmation)
Slider component (range input with value display)
MultiSelect component (checkbox list or tag selector)
CodeEditor component (for custom CSS/JS, syntax highlighting)
Store settings in WordPress options table
Cache settings in object cache (if available)
All classes, methods, functions have full PHPDoc blocks
All methods have return type declarations
No any types, no mixed without documentation
ESLint with WordPress preset for JS/TS
CI/CD fails on any linting errors
Test database setup (separate from dev database)
Unit tests for all core classes
Unit tests for all helper functions
Mock WordPress functions where needed (using Mockery or WP_Mock)
Test edge cases (empty inputs, null, invalid types)
Test data providers for multiple inputs
Test exceptions (expect specific exceptions to be thrown)
Test coverage: 100% for critical paths (security, data integrity)
Test teardown (clean up after each test)
Integration tests for database operations (insert, update, delete)
Integration tests for cron jobs (if any)
Integration tests with real WordPress environment
Integration tests with popular plugins (WooCommerce, etc.)
Manual security audit of all input points
File upload security testing (malicious file detection)
Command injection testing (no shell commands with user input)
SSRF testing (no server-side requests with user-controlled URLs)
Sensitive data in logs (no passwords, API keys in logs)
Security headers check (CSP, HSTS, X-Content-Type-Options, etc.)
Database query time monitoring (under 100ms per query)
Keyboard navigation testing (Tab, Enter, Esc, Arrow keys)
Color contrast checking (4.5:1 for text, 3:1 for large text)
Non-color indicators (don't rely on color alone)
Link text clarity ('View Product X' vs. 'Click here')
Mobile browser compatibility: Chrome, Safari, Firefox
Theme compatibility: Twenty Twenty-Four, Astra, GeneratePress
Page builder compatibility: Elementor, Beaver Builder, Divi
Plugin compatibility: WooCommerce, Yoast SEO, Contact Form 7
Caching plugin compatibility: WP Rocket, W3 Total Cache, LiteSpeed Cache
Security plugin compatibility: Wordfence, iThemes Security
Implement rate limiting on submission form (3/hour per IP)
Store rate limit data in transients (set_transient())
Return 429 Too Many Requests on limit exceeded
Whitelist administrator IPs from rate limiting
Configurable rate limit thresholds in settings
Different limits for authenticated vs. anonymous users
Clear rate limit data after timeout
Rate limit statistics in admin dashboard
Rate limit reset option in admin
CAPTCHA toggle in settings (disabled by default)
Math CAPTCHA: generate random math problem (2 + 3 = ?)
Store correct answer in session (not exposed to client)
Image CAPTCHA: generate distorted text image (local, no external service)
Use GD or Imagick for image generation
CAPTCHA only after X failed attempts (configurable)
CAPTCHA only for anonymous users (skip for logged-in)
No external CAPTCHA service code (no reCAPTCHA, hCaptcha, etc.)
Remove all external update API calls
No analytics or telemetry on plugin usage
No Guzzle in production (use wp_remote_request() instead)
No Monolog in production (use error_log() or custom logger)
No Symfony components in production (unless absolutely necessary)
Evaluate every dependency: is it truly needed?
For each dependency: can we replace with WordPress functions or custom code?
Document why each production dependency is included
Use composer install --no-dev for production build
Security audit of all dependencies (composer audit)
Every class has PHPDoc block with @package, @since, @version
Every method has PHPDoc block with description
Every method has @param tags with type, name, description
Every method has @return tag with type and description
Every method has @throws tag if exceptions are thrown
Every property has PHPDoc block with @var type
Deprecated functions marked with @deprecated and alternative
TODO comments with ticket reference and assignee
FIXME comments with priority (P0, P1, P2)
Complex code has inline comments explaining logic
Use phpDocumentor or Sami to generate API docs
Include all classes, interfaces, traits, functions
Installation guide (manual and WordPress admin methods)
Quick start guide (add first product in 5 minutes)
Custom post type and taxonomy details
Focus indicators visible (2px solid outline, high contrast)
Heading hierarchy correct (H1 → H2 → H3, no skipping levels)
Landmark regions marked with role or HTML5 elements
ARIA labels on all interactive elements without visible text
ARIA-live regions for dynamic content updates
Color contrast: 4.5:1 for normal text, 3:1 for large text, 3:1 for UI components
Don't rely on color alone (use icons, text, patterns)
Text resizable to 200% without loss of content or functionality
Form labels associated with inputs (<label for='id'>)
Required fields marked with required attribute and visually
Error messages descriptive and linked to inputs
Success messages announced to screen readers
All images have alt text (empty for decorative)
Link text descriptive ('View Product X' not 'Click here')
New window links warned ('opens in new window')
Button text descriptive ('Save Settings' not just icon)
Modal dialogs trap focus, ESC key closes
Modal dialogs return focus on close
Perceivable: Text alternatives for non-text content
Perceivable: Captions and alternatives for time-based media
Perceivable: Content adaptable (different ways to view)
Operable: Enough time to read and use
Operable: Navigable (skip links, headings, focus order)
Level AA: Images of text avoided (use real text)
Level AA: Multiple ways to find pages
Level AA: Headings and labels descriptive
Level AA: Language of page identified
Level AA: Language of parts identified
Level AA: On focus, no unexpected context change
Level AA: On input, no unexpected context change
Level AA: Error prevention (legal, financial, data)
Level AA: Status messages programmatically determined
Form fields announced with labels and errors
Heading hierarchy clear when navigating by headings
Link purpose clear from link text
Button purpose clear from button text
Image alt text descriptive and concise
Tables have proper headers and captions
Lists properly marked up (ul, ol, dl)
No empty elements that cause confusion
Test on fresh WordPress installation (no other plugins)
Verify no orphaned data after uninstall
Test with no internet connection (offline mode)
Test with custom table prefix (wp_, custom_, site1_)
Test with custom wp-content directory name
Test with custom plugin directory name
Test on Nginx with WordPress rules
Test on different server OS (Ubuntu, CentOS, Windows Server)
Test with different PHP memory limits (128MB, 256MB, 512MB)
Test with different max upload sizes (2MB, 10MB, 64MB)
Test with different PHP extensions enabled/disabled
Test with CDN (Cloudflare, KeyCDN - verify compatibility)
Test with security plugins (Wordfence, iThemes Security)
Network tab shows zero external requests
No console errors related to failed external loads
All images load from local server
All fonts load from local system stack
No CDN calls in source code
No Google Fonts calls in source code
Run grep -Ri 'https?://' dist/ vendor/ in plugin directory
Verify only results are user-entered affiliate links
No gravatar.com (use local avatars if needed)
No external API endpoints (except user affiliate links)
Source code review: no external @import in CSS
Source code review: no external src in HTML
Source code review: no external script tags
Source code review: no external link tags (except preconnect for user domains)
Source code review: no wp_remote_get() except for user-triggered actions
All assets in dist/ are bundled and minified
No telemetry or phone-home code present
All SQL queries use prepared statements
All nonces verified before state changes
All capabilities checked before privileged operations
No direct file access (check ABSPATH defined)
No eval() or similar dangerous functions
No shell_exec() or exec() with user input
File uploads strictly validated (type, size, content)
No PHP files accepted in uploads
Rate limiting on all forms and API endpoints
CSRF protection on all state-changing actions
XSS protection on all user-generated content
SQL injection protection on all database operations
Path traversal protection on file operations
Open redirect protection on redirect handler
No sensitive data in logs or error messages
No exposed debug information in production
No hardcoded credentials or API keys
Trigger on: push to main, pull request to main
Job: Security scan (npm audit, composer audit)
Copy plugin files to package directory
Include: *.php (main plugin file, includes, admin, public)
Exclude: build/ (build scripts, not included in package)
Run grep -R -i 'https?://' dist/ vendor/ - should return zero external domains (except comments)
Verify no googleapis.com, google.com, cdnjs.com, etc.
Verify no PHP errors or warnings in debug log
Test offline mode (no internet, plugin functions fully)
Network tab: zero outbound requests (except user affiliate clicks)
Spin up fresh WordPress install (Docker or local server)
Disable internet connection on test environment
Access admin pages - should load fully
Verify zero external requests (all should fail or not exist)
No console errors related to failed external resources
All functionality works: CRUD, filtering, submission, etc.
Affiliate link redirects work (to external sites, which will fail, but redirect logic works)
Plugin header comment (Name, Plugin URI, Description, Version, Author, License)
README.txt updated (tested up to, stable tag)
Fresh WordPress installation with plugin installed
Sample products: 50-100 diverse products across categories

Sample brands: mix of well-known brands
Sample ribbons: Best Seller, New, Sale, Trending
Demo pages showing different layouts (grid, list, slider)
Demo pages showing filter and sort functionality
Demo page with single product view
Homepage with hero and featured products
Demo admin credentials (viewer role, limited access)
Settings page visible (locked to prevent changes)
Dark mode toggle on demo site
Link to documentation from demo site
Headline: 'The Enterprise-Level Affiliate Product Showcase Plugin for WordPress'
Subheadline: '100% Standalone. Zero External Dependencies. Privacy-First.'
Animated GIFs for complex features (filter, sort, etc.)
Social media graphics (1200×628 for Facebook, 1024×512 for Twitter)
Submit plugin via Add Your Plugin form
Wait for plugin review (1-2 weeks typically)
Once approved, commit to SVN repository
Upload screenshots and banner to assets/ folder in SVN
Create GitHub release for version tag (e.g., v1.0.0)
Release description: changelog with all features
Link to demo site in release notes
Link to documentation in release notes
Mention notable features in release notes
Dedicated documentation site (docs.affiliateshowcase.com or GitHub Pages)
Clean, searchable documentation theme (Docsify, MkDocs, etc.)
Sections: Getting Started, Features, Shortcodes, Hooks, Settings, FAQs
Version selector (docs for each major version)
GitHub Issues (for bug reports and feature requests)
FAQ page (constantly updated based on common questions)
Support response time: under 24 hours for email, under 48 hours for forum
Clear issue templates on GitHub (bug report, feature request)
Submit to WordPress news sites (WPTavern, etc.)
Post in relevant Facebook groups (WordPress, affiliate marketing)
Keyword research (affiliate plugin, product showcase, WordPress affiliate, etc.)
Internal linking between docs, blog posts, and main pages
External backlinks (reach out for guest posts, mentions)
Fast page load times (Core Web Vitals optimized)
Sitemap submitted to Google Search Console
Monitor support channels daily (WordPress.org, GitHub, email)
Prioritize bugs and security issues (fix within 24-48 hours)
Monthly minor releases (bug fixes, small improvements)
Notify users of updates (via WordPress admin notice)
Monitor analytics: downloads, active installs, ratings
Respond to all reviews (thank positive, address negative)
Community engagement (respond to discussions, tweets, etc.)
Iterate on UX based on user feedback and analytics
